results.title: Go Bang – PNAU
results.brief_description: Australian dance act PNAU are celebrated for groundbreaking visuals in their live act and music videos, including for their single Go Bang (2017) which featured Kira Divine. The clip creates a psychedelic, cosmic journey through animation, the glow-in-the-dark effects and an aquatic aesthetic.

constellations_primary.name: Go Bang
constellations_primary.description: Australian dance act PNAU are renowned for groundbreaking visuals in their music videos, including for their 2017 single 'Go Bang' which featured Kira Divine.

results.description: Australian dance act PNAU are celebrated for groundbreaking visuals in their live act and music videos, including for their single ‘Go Bang’, which featured Kira Divine. Setting out to create a psychedelic, cosmic journey through the use of animation, the glow-in-the-dark effects and aquatic aesthetic conjure images of James Cameron’s Avatar and the introduction of singing crab Tamatoa in Disney’s Moana.
description_for_label: Australian dance act PNAU are celebrated for groundbreaking visuals in their live act and music videos, including for their single ‘Go Bang’, which featured Kira Divine. Setting out to create a psychedelic, cosmic journey through the use of animation, the glow-in-the-dark effects and aquatic aesthetic conjure images of James Cameron’s Avatar and the introduction of singing crab Tamatoa in Disney’s Moana.

results.title: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.brief_description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ (2011) by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube.
results.title_for_label: Somebody I Used To Know – Gotye ft. Kimbra
results.description: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.
description_for_label: One of the first music videos to go viral in the age of the internet, ‘Somebody That I Used to Know’ by Gotye (and featuring Kimbra) has been viewed over 1.3 billion times on YouTube. The use of body paint and early animation technique stop motion helped drive the track to a No.1 hit in the US and Australia, as well as countless comedic parodies and rip-offs in the intervening years.

results.title: Great Southern Land – Icehouse
results.brief_description: Although it looks like it was shot in Central Australia, Icehouse’s music video for ‘Great Southern Land’ was actually filmed in a disused quarry in Sydney. A second music video was made for the song to tie-in with its use in Young Einstein.

constellations_primary.name: Great southern land?
constellations_primary.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.description: Although it looks like it was shot in the heart of Central Australia, Icehouse’s music video for their most popular track – ‘Great Southern Land’ – was actually filmed in a disused quarry in the Sydney suburb of Wahroonga. Solarised clips and shots of a campfire at night help capture the sense of isolation in the lyrics. A second music video was made for the song several years later to tie-in with its use in Young Einstein (1988).
description_for_label: Although it looks like it was shot in the heart of Central Australia, Icehouse’s music video for their most popular track – ‘Great Southern Land’ – was actually filmed in a disused quarry in the Sydney suburb of Wahroonga. Solarised clips and shots of a campfire at night help capture the sense of isolation in the lyrics. A second music video was made for the song several years later to tie-in with its use in Young Einstein (1988).

results.title: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.brief_description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for Dream A Little Crazy (2013) is no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy.

constellations_primary.name: Dream A Little Crazy: The next stage of human evolution
constellations_primary.description: Collaborators Lucy McRae and Rachel Wingfield created a ‘biological bakery’ for Architecture In Helsinki’s "Dream A Little Crazy". Manufacturing a series of mass-produced band members the clip explores speculative science and the future of the human body’s evolution.

results.title_for_label: Dream a Little Crazy – Architecture in Helsinki
results.description: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.
description_for_label: Renowned for their colourful and crazy videos, Architecture in Helsinki’s clip for ‘Dream A Little Crazy’ was no exception. A collaboration between body architect Lucy McRae and designer Rachel Wingfield, the music video presents a “biological bakery” as it creates an edible anatomy. The Melbourne alt-pop darlings pointed to properties such as The Rocky Horror Picture Show (1975), Weird Science (1985) and Frankenstein as influences for the concept.

results.title: My Hometown – Munro Melano
results.brief_description: When he was just 17-years old, drummer Leon Isackson started capturing his life on the road from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown ‘ (2014).

constellations_primary.name: My Hometown: Archives woven into new narrative
constellations_primary.description: Offering viewers a snapshot of life on the road for an Australian touring band in the 1960s, 'My Hometown', directed by Sari Braithwaite was developed reimagining archival 8mm footage shot by drummer Leon Isackson.

results.description: Leon Isackson is considered one of Australia’s greatest drummers, having played with everyone from John Farnham to Johnny O’Keefe and Little Pattie. When he was just 17-years-old, he started capturing his life on the road as a touring musician for six years from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown’.
description_for_label: Leon Isackson is considered one of Australia’s greatest drummers, having played with everyone from John Farnham to Johnny O’Keefe and Little Pattie. When he was just 17-years-old, he started capturing his life on the road as a touring musician for six years from 1959 onwards with these clips – shot on 8MM film – combined to capture a nostalgic period of Australian music and form the video for Munro Melano’s ‘My Hometown’.

results.title: Long Way to the Top – AC/DC
results.credit_line: ℗ 1976 J. Albert & Sons Pty Ltd. (Young / Scott / Young)
results.brief_description: The music video for AC/DC’s hit that featured the ban travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston street on the back of a truck, which helped lead to the band having a laneway named after them.

constellations_primary.name: The secret life of suburbia and music videos
constellations_primary.description: Australia's famous streets and suburbs have defined music videos, TV shows and miniseries, providing a unique backdrop to Australian stories and music.

results.description: Countdown (1974–87) was not only one of the first television programs in the world to regularly play music videos, but it also created clips for local acts such as It’s A Long Way To The Top (1976) for AC/DC. The footage of the band travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston Street on the back of a truck as they perform live became so iconic, it led to the city naming a key piece of geography after them in 2004: ACDC Lane.
description_for_label: Countdown (1974–87) was not only one of the first television programs in the world to regularly play music videos, but it also created clips for local acts such as It’s A Long Way To The Top (1976) for AC/DC. The footage of the band travelling down Melbourne’s Swanston Street on the back of a truck as they perform live became so iconic, it led to the city naming a key piece of geography after them in 2004: ACDC Lane.

results.title: Native Tongue – Mo’Ju
results.credit_line: ℗ 2018 Mojo Juju, exclusively licensed to Australian Broadcasting Corporation. (de Luzuriaga / Ma / Seumanutafa)
results.brief_description: Deceptively simple, Mo’Ju’s ‘Native Tongue’ it uses a single shot of the singer and three Djuki Mala dancers walking through an unmistakably Australian landscape. The glitch effect utilised not only adds visual emphasis to the on-screen movement, but also underlines the poignant lyrics.

constellations_primary.name: Native Tongue
constellations_primary.description: The lead single off her album of the same name, 'Native Tongue' saw artist Mo'Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals.

results.description: The lead single off their album of the same name, Native Tongue (2018) saw artist Mo’Ju explore cultural identity through music, movement and striking visuals. Deceptively simple, it uses a single shot of Mo’Ju and three Djuki Mala dancers walking through an unmistakably Australian landscape. The glitch effect utilised not only adds visual emphasis to the on-screen movement, but also underlines the poignant lyrics.

results.title: Image contagion
results.brief_description: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny.

constellations_primary.name: Confronting injustice on-screen
constellations_primary.description: The Black Lives Matter movement and the treatment of African Americans at the hands of authorities is explored in this Constellation that connects hip-hop, the Civil Rights Movement and representation in Hollywood.

results.description: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. Our relationship to the moving image has shifted from consumption to production. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny. Coupled with social media, the moving image can affect political, social and cultural change; smartphones are able to help topple governments, transmit ideas and defend civil rights. Yet the moving image is also easily manipulated, making it an important arena in the battle for reality.
description_for_label: Smartphones democratised the moving image. With the power to record at our fingertips, we’re able to share information, bear witness and incite action. Our relationship to the moving image has shifted from consumption to production. By capturing events from multiple perspectives, we have the power to challenge official narratives, speak truth to power and expose tyranny. Coupled with social media, the moving image can affect political, social and cultural change; smartphones are able to help topple governments, transmit ideas and defend civil rights. Yet the moving image is also easily manipulated, making it an important arena in the battle for reality.

results.title: Documenting Australia
results.brief_description: Documenting Australia is a section in Moving Minds that explores how the identity of a nation can be crafted through the moving image.

constellations_primary.name: Women in charge
constellations_primary.description: Across documentary, film, TV, and visual art, Aboriginal women have led how they will be represented on-screen.

results.description:
The identity of a nation can be crafted through the moving image. While Australian narrative features say a lot about us as a people, few forms can cut through to the essence of Australia more acutely than documentary.  

In the post-war period, it emerged as one of the most important art forms in the local industry for its educational, political and social power. During the 1970s, documentary became an integral way for First Peoples to represent their experience on an unprecedented scale.

Decades later, documentary has endured and evolved as a way to amplify countless voices and ideas.
description_for_label:
The identity of a nation can be crafted through the moving image. While Australian narrative features say a lot about us as a people, few forms can cut through to the essence of Australia more acutely than documentary.  

In the post-war period, it emerged as one of the most important art forms in the local industry for its educational, political and social power. During the 1970s, documentary became an integral way for First Peoples to represent their experience on an unprecedented scale.

Decades later, documentary has endured and evolved as a way to amplify countless voices and ideas.

results.title: Documenting reality
results.brief_description: Documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. They have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.

constellations_primary.name: Reality TV me
constellations_primary.description: Cult documentary Grey Gardens follows the everyday eccentricities of mother and daughter Big Edie and Little Edie. The women perform and speak candidly to the camera, and have been described as predecessors to reality TV stars.

results.description: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.
description_for_label: The very first films could be considered documentaries. Founders of the moving image, like Thomas Edison and the Lumière brothers, captured shorts of real life, called ‘actuality films’, at the turn of the 20th century. In the decades since, documentary has evolved from educational newsreels and public service announcements to the experimental cinéma vérité (‘truthful cinema’), docuseries and online videos. Documentary films have provided insight into others, revealed distant locations and forged deep connections between audiences and stories. But they have also been used to spread propaganda and influence society, projecting interpretations of the truth that highlight the problematic relationship between cinema and reality.
